{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3112886,"name":"","username":"wellesleyfrc","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ebca7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-21T19:07:41.848Z","cooked":"

We are trying to CNC gussets out of 1/8” aluminum sheet metal, however, our Iconic CNC went rogue. For the first 10 minutes, the CNC was successfully outlining the pattern for a T gusset. Then the CNC suddenly started drilling too deep and began outlining the T gusset in the wrong places. Eventually, the CNC stopped due to its emergency fuse. The tip of the drill bit melted. The drill bit is a #46282-K from Spektra, which is meant to CNC aluminum.

What do you think caused this issue? How can we successfully CNC metal gussets?

See the following images.

image1920×1440 176 KB

image1920×1440 267 KB

image1920×1440 325 KB

Thanks in advance

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-22T14:28:27.838Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2014,"reads":419,"readers_count":418,"score":10138.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/b/db79647596e865ea4b740a30ea52ee87614b0ee2.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/b/6/b669a54a4c46ed348fd191500f21dc79a944b520.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/9/8/98eb685cbeca5882ce34ed85b691925cb0add094.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/1","custom_user_title":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns","reactions":[{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3112893,"name":"","username":"Hollisms","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hollisms/{size}/110925_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-21T19:18:10.737Z","cooked":"

If the device is still on send it to 0,0,0. Depending where that is NOW will be a clue. (Be careful on the zero on Z you may have to stop it.)

Thanks for your suggestion. We already shut off the machine yesterday and turned it back on today, so I’m not sure if we can find the origin of the CNC drill bit position

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-21T19:22:47.492Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":391,"readers_count":390,"score":93.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":36169,"username":"Hollisms","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hollisms/{size}/110925_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/3","custom_user_title":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3112900,"name":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","username":"Skuke","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skuke/{size}/10109_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-21T19:37:51.642Z","cooked":"

I was working on a CNC mill (Anilam) many, many, years ago. There was, I think, some kind of power surge. The CNC had a brain fart and did something similar. …Just went crazy and ruined a part. The XYZ zeros were all lost.

FWIW, I got blamed for ruining an expensive part despite the fact that no programming changes were made and several parts were made before and after the incident with no problems.
But, I got some redemtion when the owner’s son ruined another job on the same machine with the same type of error! …he said it wasn’t his fault either!
Anyhow, the machine got some better grounding and it never happened again. But then, it never happened before my incident either.
Don’t know if it makes a difference, but my incident also occured in the winter/rainy season.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-21T19:37:51.642Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":387,"readers_count":386,"score":157.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3112927,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-21T21:30:26.249Z","cooked":"

You have more problems than the CNC suddenly jumping to cut another part. You have melted aluminum all around your cut slots. The tip of the bit did not melt. The aluminum melted and stuck to the bit. I’m amazed it cut as long as it did without breaking the bit. At some point, it was just melting aluminum and pushing it aside. It wasn’t cutting anything.

Also, the bit you mention, Amana 46282-K with the Spektra coating, is not designed to cut aluminum. Aluminum is not in the huge list of recommended materials on the web page. Also, if you’ve got the bit number correct, it is a tapered ballnose carving bit. It is not designed to slot-cut anything. It’s also got FOUR flutes, which is a disaster waiting to happen with aluminum.

If you like Amana bits and have a 1/4" collet, get yourself a 51456. Single “O” flute, upcut, uncoated. There are also lots of other less expensive bits for aluminum mentioned across CD. Just search for router bit.

What speed, feed, and depth of cut were you trying to run? For a 3/16" single flute bit you could probably start out with something like 15-20K rpm, 20-40 ipm, and a 1/16" depth. You may be able to get much more aggressive with the machine you have, but that’s a starting range. Don’t baby the feed rate. When fed too slow, a bit will rub and melt the material, not cut into it and make a chip. If you are worried about overdoing it, start with a really shallow cut depth like 1/32" or even less just to prove that things are working OK.

It’s really helpful when cutting aluminum to at least use an air blast to expel the cut chips from the slot. Recutting chips is a great way to melt aluminum, even with the right bit, speed, and feed. Misting a lubricant makes cutting aluminum even easier. If you don’t have a mister, simply brushing some WD-40 on the plate can be useful. Lubricants designed for CNC routing like KoolMist or MagLube are better and less toxic.

You still have an issue with the machine not cutting the path you want, but you need to deal with the melting aluminum problem as well.

Bit","clicks":22},{"url":"https://www.amanatool.com/46282-k-cnc-2d-and-3d-carving-5-4-deg-tapered-angle-ball-tip-1-16-dia-x-1-32-radius-x-1-x-1-4-shank-x-3-inch-long-x-4-flute-solid-carbide-up-cut-spiral-spektratm-extreme-tool-life-coated-router-bit.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"46282-K CNC 2D and 3D Carving 5.4 Deg Tapered Angle Ball Tip 1/16 Dia x 1/32 Radius x 1 x 1/4 Shank x 3 Inch Long x 4 Flute Solid Sub Micrograin Carbide Spektra™ Extreme Tool Life Coated Router Bit","clicks":14}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":32}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":29},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":32,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3112940,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-21T22:24:29.864Z","cooked":"

If you haven’t run this program before, I’d start by checking your Gcode in a Gcode viewer just to double check that the CAM didn’t have a brain fart. At my old job we had a crappy CAM extension for SolidWorks than would sometimes skip chunks of code when exporting, and depending on exactly how your machine works that could look the same as screwed up zeros.

If you don’t find any problems with the code try dry running some code without a bit or material to cut. If behaves, and you can find any other problems you might be best off to just keep a close eye on in case of repeat offenses.

Unfortunately, sometimes you can never completely figure out electrical problems. We had several FTAs and an electrical engineer coach try to figure out what caused the electrical problems on our robot during the 2018 Einstein finals and we never found a definite cause at the time or in the weeks after. That robot never had a similar problem before or since and it played over 100 matches.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-21T22:24:46.225Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":288,"readers_count":287,"score":102.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/6","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3112957,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-22T00:49:29.466Z","cooked":"

Do your axis have feedback sensors or servos, or is it all just open loop steppers?

Could be skipping steps during retract or collision.

When you’re rubbing and dragging and melting in a part like that, the bit can get stuck and not fully retract on a commanded stepper motion. Meanwhile, if it is an open loop stepper control, the machine won’t know that the z-axis didn’t travel, and will continue the cut as if it had retracted.

Then the same thing when it tries to high speed jog, But is caught for a moment, resulting in another offset.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-22T00:49:29.466Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":120.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3112986,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-22T02:04:40.994Z","cooked":"

This is loss of steps!

You filled your end mill flutes with Aluminum, got a good round of friction stir welding going, and then it broke free for the “lift up and go to the start point for the next round”, and plunged back into solid metal instead of the original cut.

Its very much like a 3D printer getting hung up on boogers sticking up from a print…

With Aluminum, you’ve got an “it depends” problem… Faster feed is generally a good thing, but you need good chip clearance.

A small air nozzle hitting the cut would help you a lot. A little lube will also help. A mister could combine those two, but you need to be gently with the lube or you will get a huge mess. An airbrush compressor or a big fish tank air pump or something similar is a good way to get the air for the air nozzle.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-22T02:04:40.994Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":103.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113097,"name":"","username":"wellesleyfrc","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ebca7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-22T18:36:45.150Z","cooked":"

LOL! We’ll see if we can convince the engineering teacher to let us try CNCing metal again. How did the machine get better grounding?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-22T18:36:45.150Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":32540,"username":"Skuke","name":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skuke/{size}/10109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/9","custom_user_title":"ultraviole(n)t_unicorns","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113114,"name":"Aron Rubin","username":"AronRubin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aronrubin/{size}/180072_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-22T19:40:22.975Z","cooked":"

This will sound harsher than I intend it, so read in a friendly voice: I am not a CNC expert but to my eye, you have issues with choice of tooling, operation order, speeds & feeds, and fixturing. The tool you showed was for v-carving or finishing a 3d surface cut. Never use that for plunging.

  1. Try cutting some rectangular blanks first if you can (on a bandsaw). Leave a healthy margin. now you don’t have to relocate your zero; it is at the corner of the blank.
  2. Ensure your spoilboard is parallel to the machine. From the picture it looks like a wooden spoilboard. This is done with a fly-cutter, large endmill, or by meticulously measuring and shimming. If you don’t do this your stock/blank is not at a known z-hight and you will engage with the surface unpredictably.
  3. Mark or pin your working zero to create a repeatable reference for all things you want to cut
  4. Secure your blank with edge-clamps or double-sided tape. Note this only works well enough for the initial down-force-only operations.
  5. (optional) Center drill the holes with a center drill tool. If you are using clamps make sure you have a large Z-retract between zeroing and each drill to avoid crashing into the clamps.
  6. Drill the holes with the appropriate diameter drills for your design. If you are using clamps make sure you have a large Z-retract between zeroing and each drill to avoid crashing into the clamps.
  7. Switch to screws in the holes you just drilled for clamping. Use flanged screws or washers to distribute the force. At least screw down the ends of the part and the middle to prevent buckling. If you used clamps to start, remove them now.
  8. Rough out the perimeter using a roughing end mill. If you are going to plunge try spiraling or ramping down. Alternatively, you could come from the side closest to the edge.
  9. Do a finishing cut with either a finishing end mill or the rougher if you can clean up after.
  10. (optional) use a chamfer mill to deburr the edges (and make it more finished looking). You can manually use a deburring tool instead.

wellesleyfrc:

How did the machine get better grounding?

I didn’t do the work and it was a long time ago. What I recall is a hole was drilled thru the cement foundation and a copper rod, maybe 5/8" (?) diameter, was pounded into the ground/Earth. A cable was clamped to that rod, sticking up and out of the foundation a few inches, and the other end was grounded inside the control “box” somewhere.

Also, the mill was connected to a computer with a RS-232 cable. That cable was replaced with one that had better shielding.

Definitely looks like the tool was not actually cutting but melting as has been mentioned, and then skipped steps on the motor. You definitely want single flute for a router. I use the below bit at ~13k RPMs.

Amana Tool 51377-Z SC Spiral O Single Flute Aluminum Cutting 1/4 D x 3/4 CH x 1/4 SHK x 2 Inch Long Up-Cut ZrN Coated Router Bit withMirror Finish

(there is a 1/8" version for any holes < 1/4")

This is slightly geared towards a tormach which is a more substantial machine but you are also going into less aggressive material

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T15:26:42.065Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420060,"topic_slug":"cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit","display_username":"Aron Rubin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uw8uL2jjEBs","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Maker, Mild-Tempered Scientist, Overly Seasoned Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/cnc-suddenly-drills-too-deep-and-burns-drill-bit/420060/13","custom_user_title":"Maker, Mild-Tempered Scientist, Overly Seasoned Engineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113351,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T17:22:16.790Z","cooked":"

Note that the video in the above post is not “slightly geared towards a tormach”. It is very specific to a Tormach or other CNC mill which has optimal spindle speeds in the 3000-5000 rpm range. Chances are high that a router spindle is not designed to run nearly that slow. Air-cooled router spindles typically require a minimum speed in the 9K-12K rpm range for proper cooling. Router controllers may not allow a setpoint below 9K-12K, but if they do, the spindle is going to be operating far below its rated power when run in the speed range of a mill.

If you want to try the NYC CNC Speeds & Feeds Worksheet shown in the video, try something like this for a router and aluminum.

Carbide bits in aluminum should easily be able to handle 800 surface feet per minute. 0.002 inches per tooth chip load is a nice lighter-end bite for a 3/16" tool that should make chips and not rub.

Also note that the worksheet in the video recommends a starting depth of cut of 0.25". You definitely don’t want to start there for slotting (cutting out a gusset). The worksheet assumes that the bit will be performing a clearing operation with the width of cut from 5-25% of the bit diameter. I would not start with greater than 1/16" depth of cut for slotting until you understand more about your machine rigidity and power.
